articles.headline: In 2009, Layoffs Is the Business to Be In
articles.snippet: “Career transition” firms are growing even as they help other companies shrink.
articles.abstract: “Career transition” firms are growing even as they help other companies shrink.
articles.lead_paragraph: As companies across the country eliminate hundreds of thousands of jobs, one field is hiring: the layoff industry. Businesses that specialize in “career transition” can barely keep up with the demand as corporate America cuts staff.

articles.headline: Alliance With Fiat Gives Chrysler Another Partner and Lifeline
articles.snippet: Fiat said it would take a 35 percent stake in Chrysler, giving it the ability to market its cars through Chrysler’s dealership network. Chrysler will have access to Fiat’s technology.
articles.abstract: Fiat said it would take a 35 percent stake in Chrysler, giving it the ability to market its cars through Chrysler’s dealership network. Chrysler will have access to Fiat’s technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Chrysler has flirted with bankruptcy at several points in its 84-year history, only to come back from the brink with new management, a new owner, a hot new product or a financial lifeline from the government.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Nation’s Many Faces in Extended First Family
articles.snippet: The new president was sworn in while surrounded by a clan that redrew the image of the first family.
articles.abstract: The new president was sworn in while surrounded by a clan that redrew the image of the first family.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The president’s elderly stepgrandmother brought him an oxtail fly whisk, a mark of power at home in Kenya. Cousins journeyed from the South Carolina town where the first lady’s great-great-grandfather was born into slavery, while the rabbi in the family came from the synagogue where he had been commemorating Martin Luther King’s Birthday. The president and first lady’s siblings were there, too, of course: his Indonesian-American half-sister, who brought her Chinese-Canadian husband, and her brother, a black man with a white wife.

articles.headline: Obama Has No Quick Fix for Banks
articles.snippet: Administration advisers have cautioned that they would not be rushed.
articles.abstract: Administration advisers have cautioned that they would not be rushed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON —Even before they have settled into their new jobs, President Obama’s economic team faces an acute crisis in the nation’s banking system that has no easy answers and that they are not yet prepared to address.

articles.headline: The Economy Is Bad, but 1982 Was Worse
articles.snippet: The recession of the early 1980s doesn’t have a catchy name, and many Americans are too young to remember it. But indicators say that these were worse times then.
articles.abstract: The recession of the early 1980s doesn’t have a catchy name, and many Americans are too young to remember it. But indicators say that these were worse times then.
articles.lead_paragraph: You often hear that we are now living through the worst recession since the early 1980s, and the comparison is not wrong. But it’s ultimately unsatisfying, because it is a little too vague to be useful.

articles.headline: A Long Day Steeped in Pomp, History and Emotion
articles.snippet: Barack Obama experienced a dash of disbelief on the day in which he formally became the president.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama experienced a dash of disbelief on the day in which he formally became the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As President Obama stood on the east steps of the Capitol, waiting to review the troops in his new role as commander in chief, he discreetly moved the American flag pin from the lapel of his suit to his black wool overcoat and proceeded onto one of his first ceremonial acts of office.

articles.headline: Rejecting Bush Era, Reclaiming Values
articles.snippet: Though couched in indirect terms, the inaugural address was a stark repudiation.
articles.abstract: Though couched in indirect terms, the inaugural address was a stark repudiation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Barack Obama’s Inaugural Address on Tuesday was a stark repudiation of the era of George W. Bush and the ideological certainties that surrounded it, wrapped in his pledge to drive the United States into “a new age” by reclaiming the values of an older one.

articles.headline: From a Festive Crowd Come Chants and Tears
articles.snippet: Many in the inaugural crowd on Tuesday spoke of their own recognition of shock, an identifiable moment in which Barack Obama’s presidency suddenly became real.
articles.abstract: Many in the inaugural crowd on Tuesday spoke of their own recognition of shock, an identifiable moment in which Barack Obama’s presidency suddenly became real.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From overhead and on television, the inaugural throng on Tuesday resembled a singular human blanket sprawling over miles. Up close, what was striking were the tears, visible up and down the Mall and the parade route, dripping from the eyes of adults, children, at all points of the day.

articles.headline: Obama Takes Oath, and Nation in Crisis Embraces the Moment
articles.snippet: Barack Hussein Obama called on Americans to confront “our collective failure to make hard choices.”
articles.abstract: Barack Hussein Obama called on Americans to confront “our collective failure to make hard choices.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Barack Hussein Obama was sworn in as the 44th president of the United States on Tuesday and promised to “begin again the work of remaking America” on a day of celebration that climaxed a once-inconceivable journey for the man and his country.
